_header: Hear and see and say nought
Note:
Sometimes occur as a continuation of 4798, but probably are part of a separate tradition: see Wenzel (1978)
XWenzel, Siegfried. Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle English Poems. Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978, 141. First two lines proverbial: see Whiting (1968)
XWhiting, Bartlett Jere. Proverbs, Sentences, and Proverbial Phrases from English Writings Mainly before 1500. Cambridge, MA: Belknap, 1968, H.264.
Subjects: tongue, advice concerning use of; sermons, verse in
_description: Hold your tongue — three lines in one manuscript of the Fasciculus Morum

BodRawC670.Transcription:
Here and see and say noghtBe wyse and ware and telle noghtGoo
                    forthe by thingus and stele noght
BodRawC670.Editions:
Wenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle
                English Poems.
         Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978: 140.

CamTCC599.Transcription: Here and se and sey natBe ware & wyse & ly nat
CamTCC599.Note: Not in Fasciculus, but as lines 85-86 of 5530.

Digital Facsimile of Trinity College Cambridge MS R.3.19.
